nodes.bodyText: please remove these line breaks. Import statements should be added in only two blocks, one for static and one for non static imports. Please refer to the style guide for more detail.
please address all formatting issues across the PR.
formatted Import statements with only two blocks, one for static and one for non static imports.

doesn't look in scope, also not why we should ignore the case here?
Ignoring the code significantly reduces the complexity of the code and makes it much easier to brute force.
One of the test cases were failing for participant-manager , hence the change. Also replaced equalsIgnoreCase with equals .
I am still seeing equalsIgnoreCase here. Please change back to ==

I am fairly sure that study builder UI limits this to 15 characters.
Please make sure these conditions are exactly the same.

nodes.bodyText: No need to add a length constraint for autogenerated values. Let's go with the default.
removed length for auto generated values
Can we create a new attribute that combines all of these attributes?
I tried but din find any solution for this . I refer this urlhttps://stackoverflow.com/questions/51801494/jpa-create-a-custom-id-annotation  it is not possible it seems.
Unfortunate, Spring seems to allow this pattern so I thought it would work. Nevermind then.
This is the default so I'd just remove it
Removed this attribute
this column should not be null, we need to start pulling this value for the branding text so makes sense to ensure its not empty.
added not null constraint for this column.
feel free to remove all org related information for now

nodes.bodyText:
I had assumed this would be foreign key to a user table etc
What is expected to be stored here that requires large amount of space?
created_by and modified_by will be the user id created by the Auth server after registration
Should probably use @UpdateTimestamp instead of manually updating this
added @UpdateTimestamp for modified date column for all entities

why change this?
Also you can probably use @CreateTimestamp annotation here
To make it consistent across all the entities changed to created_on. Also added @CreationTimestamp for all the entities.
please remove orgId
We'll address this issue once all the Participant Manager PR's are approved/merged into develop to avoid too many conflicts during merge. Already one issue #688  created for this.
I think the length of enrollment token in the code is significantly smaller.

Please let us know fixed length for this property. For now we are creating 8 characters token for testing purpose However it can be any length by considering this token needs to enter by the user by enrolling into a study.

I was under the impression that participant_id would be unique across entire table.
This constraint means that you could have the same participant registered under more than one site. Is that what we want?

Yes, participant id is uniquely generated by response server using UUID. However added additional check for the same.
Please let me know if you want me to remove this constraint .

let me rephrase: is it okay for one participant_id to be registered in more than one site?
if that's not what we want, then we could make it unique per study_id instead. or unique on its own, if it gets generated within a study context, i.e. if new participant_id is generated per user, per study
Yes participant_id is generated per user, per study .Hence participant_id will be unique always when ever user enroll into a study.

and my original question:
" is it okay for one participant_id to be registered in more than one site?"
One participant_id  will not be registered in more than one site . Each time a user a enroll into a study we will having a unique participant_id per user per study per site

This index is only useful if a participant might be added to the same site more than once; it will prevent that form happening.
However from what you are explaining you need a restrictive rule; you need to make sure that a participant does not get added to a study more than once. It is more restrictive because since sites belong to studies, uniqueness at site level will make sure that the user is also not added to ant site more than once either.
Now, you are saying that participant_id is recreated per user and study, so this is what you need:


uniqueConstraint on the participants table for user_id and study_id (make sure a user_study combo is only ever associated with one participant_id)


uniqueConstraint on participants table on participant_id column if it's different than the primary key of the table; since it's an ID after all.


uniqueConstraint on participant_study_info table on participant_id column. Since there should be only one record per participant there, and we have already made sure that it is unique per study with the previous conditions.
Created an Unique constraint for the combo user_id and study_id. Also added unique constraint for participant_id  .
This is handled by the DB, so unless you need the back reference right away this probably isn't necessary.
This class is called AppInfo. Shouldn't this be AppEntity app?
changed to app now
UUIDs are strings
My bad. Changed to String now
Why exclude the id? Here and elsewhere
Not to include in logs

what is an example of the content of sharing column?
I know we had a boolean field to enable sharing of data for each participant, this is however a text column; please explain what this is used for.
I believe you missed this question.
Sorry for that. Please find the expected values for this property n/a,true,false and provided. I have cross checked from the mobile team also. Hence refactor the size to XS from text type

I don't remember ever hearing about these four values. Can you please describe what each one is used for and why we do not simply use boolean? null (not provided or not applicable) and true or false for provided values?

As implemented in FDA, we need just 3 values here : true. false, n/a
True = user has provided data-sharing permission
False = not provided
n/a = data-sharing consent is not configured for the study in WCP

then you should use Boolean:
https://www.mysqltutorial.org/mysql-boolean/
Since we want to allow for null values ("n/a") then it should be implemented with @Type(type="java.lang.Boolean") which supports Nulls.
This way at the db level this would be the mapping:



MySQL DB
MyStudies Application




0
FALSE


1
TRUE


NULL
n/a
Implemented @type(type="java.lang.Boolean") and changed the data type to Boolean from String
why not use @UpdateTimestamp?
used @CreationTimestamp for created property  across all the entities.

It looks like we are using @CreationTimestamp in PersonalizedUserReportEntity.java. Can this and @UpdateTimestamp be applied everywhere?
Can we consistent also be consistent in how we name these? It seems like it should be created_on and updated_on, or created_date and updated_date. Personally I like createdTime and updatedTime best because it's a date and time, not just a date, but use whatever you prefer, as long as it's consistent. Final note though, is there any reason we can't just use the automatically generated column names for these? Using created seems fine if that's what the name of this Java field is.
modified the column name to created_time and updated_time
What is this timestamp for? You've already got created
It is similar to created only. However removed now as it is not used in code.
modified_on for consistency?
changed to updated_time as per the suggestion
I think we need greater consistency on how booleans are represented. Sometimes they are Integer, sometimes TINYINT, sometimes 'N'.

To represent the integer value such as permissions(e.g read only(0) and read edit(1) we have used Integers. For the value such as true false, we have  used boolean . Also created Permission enum class to represent these values.

My apologies, for the old schemas we were using TINYINT, but I see it's done with the automatic mapping for boolean in this PR, so that's good. But for permissions, can you use enums with @Enumerated(EnumType.STRING) then? It's not clear what values this field can take just from looking at this class.
Included @Enumerated(EnumType.ORDINAL) now for permission related properties.
The other data object use "id" as the name for their ID. Can this one by changed without too much trouble? Ideally every data object has a primary identifier called "id"
Now changed the primary key column name id for all the entity classes.
What about the field name?
Changing the field name will lead to code refactor. For this particular entity can be done without any further changes , however for other entity classes it require code changes
Can these be non-nullable? What is their primary purpose?
This is the column to represent who created(logged in user of participant manager) this entity data.
So is this something that needs to be filled in for compliance?
yes to keep a track

how about using this pattern for naming this unique constraints:
${table_name}__#{columns names joined via "_"}_uidx
e.g.
participant_registry_site__email_study_info_id_uidx ?
Please rename other instances using the same pattern.
rename all the constraints as suggested

what happens if this flag is false here?
Would the table not be rendered?
Yes, if this property is false in respective services , then the entities will not be created.
user details table has a user_id in addition to the default Id.  what is user_id used for?
user_id is user id received from Auth server after successful registration.
this change seems like it should have a corresponding code change
tempPasswordDate is an used column, hence removed now.It  wont be impacting any code.
This is the issue I was referring to on Thursday. Looks like we aren't doing this anymore
So in this case what exactly needs to be done . If we not consider text data type , we need explicitly define the size of the column which may be huge .

I don't understand, you've marked the column as "text". But then you say Marking "columnDefinition = Text" is not portable and doesn't work in tests.. My issue is only regarding this comment, if the text is big then fine, but this comment doesn't make sense.

This particular entity was introduced by UNC team along with some added functionality and comment was added them only .  However I did the change to modify the datatype from VARCHAR to text as they have mentioned huge length of 6500. Is it okay to remove the comment if it is confusing ?
Yes, please remove comments like this if/when they are no longer relevant
removed not relevant comment from the entity class
Mentioned in my comment on the create/update timestamps, can we just remove the name attribute when it matches the property name? I don't think we need to explicitly name every column.
Removed name attribute if column name and property name are same.
String?
Changed to String now
app?
Changed to app now.
I don't think the insertable annotation is necessary
removed insertable =true and updatable = true , as these are by default true
UUID?
Modified and used UUID
Does this actually add a non-null constraint to the table?
yes this annotation is creating a Not Null Constraint
Can you put all these deletes in a helper function on testDataHelper?
Can we do this change in the upcoming PR, as this change will not be part of this PR scope.
OK
Booleans shouldn't need a length. You've only specified it on some of them as well.
Removed length for Booleans
Thanks for the suggestion and same is implemented now.
Same as above. Throughtout file
implemented as above comment and pushed the changes
this should be renamed too. If it takes a lot of work, please file a bug
Created a bug for this and will be taking care of this change in later stage of development #733
nit: can these permissions be renamed to simply VIEW and EDIT ?
I believe you missed this comment as well
rename this to VIEW and EDIT

this looks like a bug to me. We have a column disabled_time, it's set to the creation time and it is not updatable.
Is this column ever used? if not, it should be removed.
If it is used, how do we change the value?

This column should not be creation time . I revisited the implementation logic for this and found the column will only be updated when participant manager will disable a user . Hence I have removed @CreationTimestamp and added
@Column(name = "disabled_time", columnDefinition = "TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP")
this also looks like a bug. Token is immediately expired? why exactly do we need to store this time in the database then? doesn't its existence alone not indicate that it is expired?

I have gone through the implementation again , this column should not be populated with default current time stamp. Participant Manager will be updating this value to 48 hrs from the time of invitation sent with enrollment token to a participant.
then why is it still set to columnDefinition = "TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP" ?
please fix
My bad. I have removed this now .
My Bad, removed columnDefination now.
please remove extra line
same here, please remove the unnecessary separation
please remove all these unrelated formatting changes out of this CL.
